description: Hobson-Jobson of earlier forms vardingale, etc., borrowed from Middle French verdugale, from Spanish verdugado, from verdugo (“rod”).

entries.meaning: (historical) A hooped structure in cloth worn to extend the skirt of women's dresses; a hooped petticoat.
examples: In Henry VIII's Great Hall, there were men in doublets and codpieces prancing up and down with women in farthingales.
